Notes: by definition, contexts of small-scale multilingualism are highly linguistically diverse

contexts of small-scale multilingualism feature a lack of accommodation - people shifting to the language another person is using in order to create a monolingual interaction (see receptive multilingualism)
small-scale multilingual contexts tend to support many small languages
contexts of small-scale multilingualism tend not to have highly hierarchical social structure

small-scale multilingual contexts do not have polyglossia - hierarchical status differences between Indigenous languages (but colonisation may create polyglossia between national languages and Indigenous languages)
